user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskSetPriority_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_TaskSetPriority_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, osal_priority_t new_priority)
{
    int os_priority;
    int ret;

    OS_impl_task_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_task_table, *token);

    if (POSIX_GlobalVars.EnableTaskPriorities)
    {
        /* Change OSAL priority into a priority that will work for this OS */
        os_priority = OS_PriorityRemap(new_priority);

        /*
        ** Set priority
        */
        ret = pthread_setschedprio(impl->id, os_priority);
        if (ret != 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("pthread_setschedprio: Task ID = %lu, prio = %d, err = %s\n",
                     OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), os_priority, strerror(ret));
            return OS_ERROR;
        }
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_TaskSetPriority_Impl:
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_task_internal_record_t OS_impl_task_table[OS_MAX_TASKS]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_t id;
} OS_impl_task_internal_record_t
...
static inline osal_id_t OS_ObjectIdFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_id;
}
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
static inline unsigned long OS_ObjectIdToInteger(osal_id_t object_id)
{
#ifdef OSAL_OMIT_DEPRECATED
    return object_id.v;
#else
    return object_id;
#endif
}
...
static int OS_PriorityRemap(osal_priority_t InputPri)
{
    int OutputPri;

    if (InputPri == 0)
    {
        /* use the "MAX" local priority only for OSAL tasks with priority=0 */
        OutputPri = POSIX_GlobalVars.PriLimits.PriorityMax;
    }
    else if (InputPri >= OS_MAX_TASK_PRIORITY)
    {
        /* use the "MIN" local priority only for OSAL tasks with priority=255 */
        OutputPri = POSIX_GlobalVars.PriLimits.PriorityMin;
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * Spread the remainder of OSAL priorities over the remainder of local priorities
         *
         * Note OSAL priorities use the VxWorks style with zero being the
         * highest and OS_MAX_TASK_PRIORITY being the lowest, this inverts it
         */
        OutputPri = (OS_MAX_TASK_PRIORITY - 1) - (int)InputPri;

        OutputPri *= (POSIX_GlobalVars.PriLimits.PriorityMax - POSIX_GlobalVars.PriLimits.PriorityMin) - 2;
        OutputPri += OS_MAX_TASK_PRIORITY / 2;
        OutputPri /= (OS_MAX_TASK_PRIORITY - 2);
        OutputPri += POSIX_GlobalVars.PriLimits.PriorityMin + 1;
    }

    return OutputPri;
}
...
extern POSIX_GlobalVars_t POSIX_GlobalVars
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
int32 OS_TaskSetPriority_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, osal_priority_t new_priority)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The function does not assign to or modify either parameter. 'token' (a pointer to const) is only read and not reassigned, and 'new_priority' is passed by value and only used as an input to OS_PriorityRemap. The OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(*token) usage does not alter the pointer or the pointed-to object.
